title: An introduction to inferential statistical tests
text:
Overview
Whilst Session 1 (this morning) gave you the skills to describe your data, this workshop moves on to look at how you can use your data to make inferences (i.e. how to use data to test statistical hypotheses).
We will focus on training you to run and interpret the output from three basic kinds of statistical tests.

Firstly, we will look at bivariate correlation tests (useful when studying relationships between pairs of continuous variables).
Then we will take a look at t-tests (used to test for group differences in a continuously measured outcome).
Lastly, we will look at chi-squared tests (helpful for testing relationships between variables that are both measured categorically). 







Session Structure



To be added
Note: At the end of each section I’ve also included some ‘things to do next’ advice.

title: The theory underpinning frequentist inferential statistical methods
text:
Overview
In this session we will discuss the theory underpinning inferential statistical methods.
To begin, we will explain how statistical methods are used to model our predictions (i.e. our hypotheses) and how samples of data, from a larger population, are then used to test the goodness of fit between our “predicted models” and the actual data we have collected (i.e. does our data support our predictions?).
In particular, there will be a focus on helping you understanding the concepts of ‘significance’ and ‘meaningfulness’. This will involve you learning a bit about what ‘p-values’ (for Null Hypothesis Significance tests) and Effect Sizes represent and getting opportunities to practice interpreting such values.
Slides

title: Schedule for the day
text:
This website hosts supporting materials for a single day summer school, which I (Dr Liam Hill) run for MSc Education Child & Adolescent Psychology (CAP) Pathway students within MHSES, at the University of Edinburgh.
The content is broken up into three sessions, which are designed to give you an introduction to foundational statistical concepts and teach you some simple descriptive and inferential statistical methods.

Schedule for the day
0900-1030: Session 1: Describing, Visualising and Exploring Data
1100-1230: Session 2: The theory underpinning frequentist inferential statistical methods
1400-1600: Session 3: An introduction to inferential statistical tests







IMPORTANT - Looking into this before the day of the summer-school!



Please bring with you to the summer-school a device (e.g. a laptop) that has SPSS already set up and running on it.
SPSS is a statistical software that you will practice using in Sessions 1 and 3. We will NOT have time to go through installing it on the day, so please find time to do this beforehand.
The University has procedures that will allow you to request and install a FREE personal copy of this software. Further instructions on how to do this can be found at this Information Services Webpage: https://information-services.ed.ac.uk/computing/desktop-personal/software/main-software-deals/spss/spss-staff-and-students

title: Describing, Visualising and Exploring Data
text:
Overview
This session will focus on developing your understanding of how to use SPSS statistical software to analyse data Descriptively. In this session we will build your skills at reporting and describing your data (e.g. presenting and interpreting summary statistics), visualising your data (e.g. using Graphs) and exploring it (e.g. to identify outlier observations).






Session Structure




To begin with I’ll talk for about 10 min on some general points that are important to keep in mind, throughout all today’s sessions.
We will then spend about 25 mins looking at each of the three main sections of this workshop. Within each section I’ll start with a brief (5-10 min) demo of some key skills and highlight some key points before allowing some time for you to practice these skills and ask questions.

Note: At the end of each section I’ve also included some ‘things to do next’ advice.



General Introduction
Slides

SPSS Dataset for Parts 1 and 2
Walkthroughs and Exercises
Walkthroughs and Exercises with ANSWERS



1. Describing your data
Slides
For exercises demonstrating various techniques for describing your data please see pages 1-7 of the Walkthroughs doc, link above.






Further Steps



The SPSS output you’ve generated will contain ways of describing various different types of data, which you may want to report in your dissertation. It’s important to work out, from these big tables, what it is important to report (that will depend on your project) and to format that reporting appropriately for your dissertation (i.e. cut-and-pasting in SPSS output tables in generally not considered “proper formatting”)
I’ve noticed SPSS has added some functions for outputting your descriptive statistics in APA formatted tables. I’ve never used these but you may want to look into their usefulness.Alternatively, refer to a style guide, like the one linked to below, that will give you comprehensive advise on how to report descriptive statistics in both text and table format:
American Psychological Association. (2020). Publication manual of the American Psychological Association 2020: the official guide to APA style (7th ed.). American Psychological Association. https://doi.org/10.1037/0000165-000




2. Visualising your data
Slides
For exercises demonstrating various techniques for visualising your data please see pages 8-13 of the Walkthroughs doc, link above.






Further Steps



As mentioned in the Walkthroughs, there a lots of other ways you could visualise your data. Plus, there’s a need to format these graphs in a format suitable for your dissertation.
If you’re creating graphs for inclusion in your dissertation I would ALWAYS view what SPSS outputs as a ‘rough draft’ that will need editing to reduce chart clutter and to use terminology more aligned with the names/terms you are using to describe your variables in your text.
Again, the APA manual has lots of examples within its style guide of what well-formatted graphs, of various different types, should look like.
American Psychological Association. (2020). Publication manual of the American Psychological Association 2020: the official guide to APA style (7th ed.). American Psychological Association. https://doi.org/10.1037/0000165-000




3. Exploring your data
Slides
Updated SPSS Dataset for Part 3
For exercises demonstrating various things you should be looking out for when exploring your data please see pages 14-17 of the Walkthroughs doc, link above.






Further Steps



If you’ve identified outliers that you feel you it would be wise to exclude before you start your inferential analysis (either completely or as part of a sensitivity analysis), you can do this using the Select Cases function to filter them out of your dataset (See Section 3, Exercise 2, p10 of the Walkthrough doc for more info).
Once you’ve got a final set of cases you want to analyse in your dataset, It is time to consider how to test (using inferential statistical models) your hypotheses. These are predictions, formulated before you collected your data, about the relationships you expect to see between certain variables in your dataset. This ‘next step’ is what we’ll be focussing on in Session 2 and 3 today!
